question: Do I need to have prior experience in order to work at the Daily Nexus?
answer: While having experience is great, it’s not a requirement. We welcome all current UCSB students with open arms. If you’re interested in joining our art, photography, copy or production teams, you will need to submit a sample of your work.

question: Do I have to be studying journalism to work at the Daily Nexus?
answer: There’s no major requirement for joining the Nexus – our staff hails from a variety of majors, from computer engineering to English and everything in between.

question: What is the application process like?
answer: Each section has its own application, which you can find under “Our Teams” on the homepage of this website. With the exception of art, photography, copy and production, which requires applicants to submit a sample of their work, there is no need to submit a résumé or portfolio. Once the section editor receives your application, they will reach out and help you get started.

question: If I miss orientation, can I still join or do I have to wait until next quarter?
answer: The Nexus recruits year round; you can join at any time by contacting the editors of the section you are interested in. Orientation is a great place to start, but missing it is not a dealbreaker.

question: How do I contact a section editor?
answer: Editors can be reached by email. Their information can be found on their section’s page under “Our Teams” or on the Staff/Contact page of dailynexus.com.

question: Does the Nexus pay its staff members?
answer: Yes! Staff members are paid $10 per piece of content (e.g. an article, graphic, illustration, photograph or video). Editors and assistant editors are paid a regular stipend.

question: Can I work for more than one section at the same time?
answer: You can work for as many different sections as you’d like at the same time. You can also switch between sections or stick to just one – it’s entirely up to you.

question: How often will I be required to turn in work?
answer: At the Nexus, you determine how much content you’d like to produce. Most of us are juggling classes, additional jobs and extracurricular activities, so editors tend to be flexible on deadlines, as long as staff members maintain good communication.

question: How often do section meetings take place?
answer: Most sections meet on a weekly basis. During fall quarter, some sections will be meeting at the Nexus office in-person while some sections will be meeting virtually. Reach out to individual sections to get more info.

question: Are there opportunities for promotion?
answer: Yes. Throughout the year, openings for assistant positions will become available; after a training period, assistant will be promoted to section editor or co-editor.
